abstract.p: Alasdair M Stewart opens Manhattan showroom he hopes will expand sales of Rolls Royce and Bentley motorcars in North America (S)

block.p: There were no plastic pennants. ''No balloons; no bunting,'' said Alasdair M. Stewart, chief executive of Rolls-Royce Motor Cars and Bentley Motor Cars for North America. Instead, Mr. Stewart had several vintage and new cars outside -- along with Taittinger and an art show inside -- to open his new showroom on Thursday on Madison Avenue at 49th Street. That showroom is part of his strategy to bolster Rolls-Royce and Bentley sales in the United States from 672 last year to, eventually, 5,000.

There were no plastic pennants. ''No balloons; no bunting,'' said Alasdair M. Stewart, chief executive of Rolls-Royce Motor Cars and Bentley Motor Cars for North America. Instead, Mr. Stewart had several vintage and new cars outside -- along with Taittinger and an art show inside -- to open his new showroom on Thursday on Madison Avenue at 49th Street. That showroom is part of his strategy to bolster Rolls-Royce and Bentley sales in the United States from 672 last year to, eventually, 5,000.

Thanks to dot-com dollars, Mr. Stewart has succeeded in lowering the average age of Bentley buyers to 43, from 50 just 18 months ago. Ostentation run wild? No, no. With Bentleys starting at a mere $210,000, he said, ''It gets positioned more as stealth wealth than brash cash.''
